title: Northside Nepali restaurant sets opening date for former Melt space
text: Bridges is now open in Northside. Provided A Findlay Market Nepali food vendor is ready to open its first brick-and-mortar restaurant in the former Melt space in Northside. Bridges is hosting a soft opening on Thursday at 4165 Hamilton Ave. in Northside. The restaurant took possession of the space vacated by Melt after it moved down the street to the Gantry on Jan. 1 of this year. Bridges is now open in Northside. Provided "We've done farmers markets for a year and a half now, and people loved our food and always asked where they could get it outside of the markets," Bridges owner Ashak Chipalu told me. "We actually met our landlord at the Northside Farmers Market. He tried our food and showed interest in having us move into the old Melt space." Bridges has been serving South Asian and Nepalese cuisine at Findlay Market since September 2015. Chipalu's family operates restaurants in Nepal, and though he moved to the United States to pursue a career in nursing, he couldn't shake the culinary calling. All of the restaurant's offerings are based on recipes created by his mother, Rose. Nepali cuisine uses the same spice profile as Indian cooking but in a different way. The menu includes items like samosa – pastries filled with spiced potatoes and white and yellow cheddar served with a sweet and sour sauce – chips and salsa, chicken chuala and potatoes and rice bowls served with chicken tikka masala, chuala or potato curry. Bridges has seats for 48 inside and another 30 on the outdoor patio behind the restaurant. Chipalu is working on obtaining a liquor permit, so the restaurant is currently BYOB.
